awd_titl_txt: Miniconference on Aquifers as Archives of Paleoclimate
awd_abstract_narration: Isotopic and elemental composition of groundwater are                      influenced by climatic conditions at the time of recharge and are               therefore potential indicators for climate change.  To date                     little work has been done to unravel climate information                        contained in deep circulating groundwater.  However, it has been                successfully demonstrated that in selected aquifers the isotopic                composition of groundwater and the concentrations of dissolved                  noble gases can be related to paleotemperatures and/or past                     atmospheric circulation patterns.  These studies raised hopes                   that groundwater as an archive of paleoclimate may play an                      important role in future climate research, but they also indicate               that there are still many open questions that must be addressed.                This award supports a meeting at Lamont-Doherty Geological                      Observatory of Columbia University to explore the potential and                 strategies for future paleoclimate research in this area.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences
